title: Brave young boy writes heartbreaking letter to judge begging her not to send him back to violent mum
text:
Opinion 'PLEASE DON'T SEND US HOME' Brave young boy writes heartbreaking letter to judge begging her not to send him back to violent mum 
Judge Cameron ruled the mother had shaken her baby daughter and lied 'repeatedly' in evidence By Tom Wells, Chief Reporter 8th February 2017, 1:20 am Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments A BOY aged ten penned a heartbreaking letter to a judge begging her not to send him back to live with his mum-from-hell. 
The lad, his brother, five, and sister, 22 months, have been staying with foster parents since December after growing up surrounded by violence. Alamy 3 A ten-year-old boy pleads with a judge not to send him and his siblings back to their abusive mother 
The court had earlier heard how the children’s mum had hurled a Christmas tree across a room in 2015, thrown her children out of the house and yelled: “I’ve got my vodka, f*** the kids, I don’t care.” 
Experts said she had also branded them “f***ing c****”. 
After hearing the boy’s desperate plea, Judge Barbara Cameron agreed the three children should not be handed back to their mother. 3 The boy told Medway Family Court how he felt about being sent home 
The boy, known only as “B”, told Medway Family Court in Chatham, Kent, last month: “Dear Judge, I am writing to say how I feel about being taken home. 
“I feel that we should not go back to my mum’s house because she promised that she would stop drinking, arguing and fighting, but she didn’t. 
“My mum is also incapable of keeping us because she drinks all day, every day. 
“Since being in care we are happy and safe and we don’t have to worry about each other. 
“Please don’t send us home. 
“Sincerely, from B.” Mum films herself on Facebook Live beating her daughter with plywood Related stories Birmingham hotel bans asylum seekers ahead of multi-million pound refurb after guests complain SCI FI STAR DIES Battlestar Galactica star Richard Hatch dies aged 71 after pancreatic cancer battle 'IT'S GOING NUTS!' Druggy yobs film themselves feeding LSD-laced tizer and cannabis leaves to their pet HAMSTER BEAR NECESSITY We visit the overworked hospital for teddies where beloved toys are sent in for repair from all over the world 'THEY CALLED ME SALLY SHITZU' TV reporter Sally Chidzoy sues BBC bosses over 'cruel nicknames' and 'years of bullying' 'I DIDN'T KILL MY FRUIT CASE' Fiancé accused of Helen Bailey murder weeps, telling jury he 'never stopped loving' her oils well that ends well BP finally on the up after spending billions to cover 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill disaster MUCKY ESCAPE Poor hedgehog looks unrecognisable covered in mud and roots after a dog used the critter as a toy shaman you David Becks posed with Amazon tribe leader for TV show then 'snubbed him in UK' after asking him to visit GOLDEN OLDIE Disco-loving 80 year old hailed Britain's oldest DJ - despite needing a hearing aid REVENGE PORN RAP Jilted boyfriend, 36, sent explicit revenge porn photos of his ex-girlfriend to her MUM 'YOU'RE GETTING GASSED' Cops hunt sick footie yobs who sang anti-Semitic chants before Man City game against Spurs 
The boy had already given evidence in a criminal trial last October involving his mum at nearby Maidstone Crown Court. 
She was acquitted of assaulting her own brother and shaking her youngest child while intoxicated. 
The boy has since refused to see his mum or dad, a Royal Marine who lives in Plymouth on a Navy base. 
But Judge Cameron said the lad should stay in foster care. Alamy The boy gave evidence in a criminal trial involving his mother in Maidstone Crown Court last October 
She ruled the mum had shaken her baby daughter and lied “repeatedly” in evidence. 
By contrast, the judge said B was an “obviously intelligent, articulate and delightful young boy”. 
And she found his experience was “devastating” because he knew his mum had acted wrongly with his baby sister. 
The boy and his siblings will remain together with their new foster family. 
The dad had wanted the baby girl to move with him, but the judge said it would be wrong to separate them.
